description.text: I saw the pictures of the Valentine's day "sneak peak" on the NYC resistor blog, and knew that I had to make a LED heart out of PLA. (Sort of like the acrylic one here: http://www.nycresistor.com/2010/02/10/a-little-valentines-day-sneak-peek/) Obviously mine has a bit of a different form factor, and the plastic isn't transparent, but I think it's pretty nonetheless. The battery compartment is a little large, but whatever. As long as you tape the LED leads to the battery it won't jostle around much. Update: I changed the scad and stl files so that both halves of the battery compartment are on the same side when the heart is put together (thanks to owenscenic for pointing this out!) I also decreased the size of the pegs so that hopefully it won't take any drilling and/or filing to get it to fit together. Disclaimer: the pictures are photoshopped a smidgen. Because the LED I used is so bright, my camera interpreted the middle of the heart as being yellow, and the picture wasn't as vibrant as I had hoped. So I changed it.

• Print. Don't use a raft if you can avoid it.
  • Depending on your machine and your skeinforge settings, you may have to do a little drilling and filing. I drilled the holes and filed the pegs so everything fit together nicely. I've included the scad files so you can change the parameters, although they are useless without the dxf file which is hiding on a partition of my computer which I can't access at the moment.
  • Hook up the LED (a little Kapton tape helps), and stick them together!
  • (Optional) Give it to someone special to let them know you care about them.

comments.text: This looks neat. But if those are two halves, shouldn't the depression the battery sits in be on opposite sides? If the top surface of those STLs are supposed to fit together, then one needs to change. Or am i not visualizing it correctly?
comments.author: owenscenic

comments.text: ... you have an excellent point. I didn't realize that until you pointed it out. Actually it's probably a good thing that it's that way, because the depression is a little too deep, and this way it actually holds the battery in place a little better. I'll do some fixing and upload a new set of STL's later today. Thanks for pointing that out!

print_settings.Notes:: No high precision required, mechanical stability is more important. I printed in PETG.

description.text:
Hey,

this gun controller for the HTC Vive features the geometry of a G36 rifle. I designed it specifically for use in the game Onward - other games work as well of course.
Two 3d printed parts are fixed on the right hand controller by three m3 screws. The left hand controller can be freely put in and out of the horizontal housing to reload or can be used to support vertically.

The buttstock can be removed and reatached by a simple locking mechanism, so using one handed weapons is still easily possible. There are two types of locks, one only releases when manualy opened, the other one also opens on pull. (A small spring or a piece of foam can be used to hold the lock closed). The buttstock is devided in 3 parts for use in smaller printers, so it has to be glued or bolted together.

It's more or less a prototype, so there might still be some issues (especially with the locks). Biggest part has a length of about 190mm.

https://youtu.be/88r29WhZc6M

enjoy

Edit; just as a warning: Some people have trouble using it in Onward. It will not work for all gun/sight combinations, but enough usable combinations are available on both Marsoc and Volk. I've been using it succesfully for many hours in Onward.
My advice for best weapon fit is G36 or AK5C. (MP5 or G3 work quite well too)

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20% or more

Notes:

No high precision required, mechanical stability is more important. I printed in PETG.

comments.text: I printed this out and just bought Onward, and none of the guns seem to work (even the G36, regardless of the sights); my headset bangs into the butt before I can line up the sights. I'm wondering if there have been changes to the placement of the weapons in relation to the controllers to the game; can anyone else confirm? If that's the case, does anyone know of any settings changes that can be made to make it work again?
comments.author: soapdodger

comments.text:
Hey, sorry to hear.
I haven't checked in game for a few month so i can't tell you if there have been any changes to the gun placement. In general the trigger always was quite high up, for some guns you nearly had to be on eye level with your index finger for it to work. As you can see on the third picture above, if placed and scaled correctely in game there should be enough space for the headset.

comments.text: Made one of these to use in onward and played with it several hours and had a lot of trouble with it being very hard to look down the sights when the controllers were in V36 holders. One problem was that when trying to look down the sights the head set collided with the stock and it was very uncomfortable trying to twist my head to get any kind of alignment that was usable. Couldn't figure out any way to adjust or improve the alignment of the V36 and any of the guns in game.

Some gun/sight combination are just to different in form to align perfectely but are still usable...but there should be enough working combinations available on both Marsoc and Volk.
Try switch to show the controller models in game and check the alignment with the gun you want to use.

comments.text: v36-5 ended up requiring the vertical orientation, as well as soluble support material.  I started using PETG + HIPS, and dissolving the HIPS with limonene.   The final part ended up being printed with PETG + Prima PVA water soluble support.

comments.text: Hey, i think PLA should work, but i haven't tried it. You then might want to add more infill for stability though. The top screw needs to be a bit longer (about 2.5cm), so if you don't have one you can drill out the hole a bit. And if you want the locking mechanism to work optimally, you should find a small spring. Other than that i don't know of any problems ... good luck for the print :)

description.text:
I made this design because I wanted my 7inch screen in the middle of my BigBox, the current designs are asymmetric, because the PanelDue controller board is mounted directly to the backside of the screen. I made a bracket for the controller board which must be screwed at the back of the screen, and have used a 40pins (IDE) cable to connect the two. This requires some soldering (see pictures), since the connector pins are sort of mirrored on the standard 40pins connectors.

The case fits nicely in the former LCD mount of the BigBox. One word of warning: if you lower the bed below 250mm, you have to remove the screen, otherwise the bed will collide with the casing.

The design can be printed without supports.

Parts used:
9x M3x6 hex socket self tapping screw
1x 20cm 40pin GPIO Ribbon Cable
2x 40Pin 2.54mm male single row header strip

comments.text:
1: Indeed it does. Below 250mm I have to remove the case. But since cable is 50cm long, that's not really a problem, and I haven't printed anything longer that 250mm anyway.
2: Unfotunateley no, standard 40pin connectors are twisted in a stange way, pins that are left on one connector, are on the right on the oher.

description.text: A simple thing to make a triplet that can be printed then applied to another printed object using acetone or glue to help identify the 3 orthogonal axes. • print thin

  • never have to remember orientation again!

print_settings.Notes:: Update 12 November: Printed shift knob, received all hardware, test fitted & drove 500 miles round trip Tampa to Miami and back with no issues.  Lockout mechanism works with no interference, knob is solid.  ***Note: Nylock nut needs to be super-glued into its recess in the bottom half of the unit, or the knob may be slightly loose when screwed into place.

title: WRX Shift Knob Remixed for Reverse Lockout Shifters

description.text:
HUGE PROPS to WillsWorld for the original design. I just made a few easy mods to adapt this part for the newer shifters with reverse lockout.

UPDATE: The model has been printed & test fit. Like a freakin' glove. #caliperlove Inserting the letters requires a bit of finesse & just enough brute force not to break the R and X apart- just be patient & make sure to clear any wisps/stringing in the knob & the letters to make it easier.

UPDATE 2: As of July, 2017, this shift knob printed in PLA has been in my car in the Florida sun for 8-9 months. We've had a few record temps here in Tampa, plenty of mid 90's highs for the last 2 months. I do have 20% window tint all around (dark as legal in FL), but it gets plenty hot in my car & there was been no warping or softening of the plastic. Frankly, I am shocked. I figured I was going to have to re-print this in ABS or ASA by now. Curious to see if it makes it all the way through Summer. Fingers crossed.

I recently purchased a brand new, shiny 2017 WRX. Months back, I had seen Joel Telling, the 3D Printing Nerd, print & install this shifter in his 2006 WRX, and I decided that I wanted to try it myself, just for something unique.

After failing to source the necessary hardware locally, I ordered on Amazon and then went to review the files before printing. And I noticed something was a little off. The original design was not intended for vehicles with the reverse lockout feature- the one where you have to pull up on a ring under the shift knob to access Reverse. In its original form, this shift knob would have essentially disable Reverse, because there needs to be a recess for the plastic bushing above the ring to pull up into.

So I went outside & took some caliper measurements of the shifter setup in my 2017 WRX (Same generation as 2015+), and apparently, the STi had reverse lockout with the same dimensions even earlier. If you have a pre-2015 STi, it's on you to verify dimensions, etc.

I then imported the files into Tinkercad and made the needed modifications. The visible mods are all on the bottom half of the knob. The shaft that extends below the sphere is wider & a tad longer to accommodate the lockout bushing. But the top half also changed, because the opening for the shaft of the shifter was too deep, and would allow you to screw he entire contraption down so low as to possibly block your reverse lockout mechanism, again killing Reverse. So I added a few mm of material to shorten the hole so that if you screw the assembled unit all the way down, it should bottom out just as the top of the lockout busing reaches the bottom of the shifter, leaving it free to travel into the recess designed for it. (Just like stock) Also added a small indent on the top piece for a Nylock nut to fit. (Many Nylock nuts have a ridge on top)

I did NOT make any changes to the WRX lettering. I will simply include those files here.

Hardware required:
(1) m12 x 1.25 thread pitch Nylock nut.
(6) m3 x 20mm hex bolts
(6) m3 x .5mm Nylock nuts.

*Nylock nuts recommended. You could also use Loc-Tite, but make sure to chose the right variant of Loc-Tite so you don't permanently weld these things to your car. I don't remember the colors- I read the labels.

I was able to find all of these on Amazon, links below. These links are a public service only- I'm not getting an affiliate cut. And yes, these are for large quantities. Smaller quantities can be had on other web sites, but you pay a lot more per nut or bolt, and if you're 3D printing, you probably want these around anyway.

M3 x 20mm Hex Bolts, BLACK:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00W97KM4G/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1

M3 x .5mm Nylock Nuts, BLACK:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B015A3DT2W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

M12 x 1.25 thread pitch Nylock Nuts:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01FXDJ69E/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Printer:

Monoprice MakerSelect i3 v2.1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.12mm

Infill:

50% Fast Honeycomb (Simplify3D)

Notes:

I have not yet printed my shifter, as my machine is busy with another print at the moment, but the settings above are my planned settings. Both halves of the shifter are oriented to print flat-side down, so they should not require supports or rafts on most well-calibrated printers.

Update 12 November: Printed shift knob, received all hardware, test fitted & drove 500 miles round trip Tampa to Miami and back with no issues. Lockout mechanism works with no interference, knob is solid. ***Note: Nylock nut needs to be super-glued into its recess in the bottom half of the unit, or the knob may be slightly loose when screwed into place.

A few extras...

The Nylock nut needs to be super-glued into place to make sure the shift knob doesn't jiggle on the shifter. I expected as much, and my test fit confirmed it.

The 20mm screws are just long enough for the job. You could go 25mm to ensure you're getting all the way through the nuts, but you might need to add washers if you don't want the screws to protrude out the bottom of the nuts. (I just got my 25mm screws in, have not tried them yet.

I sanded my finished print with 220 & 400 grit sandpaper, gave it a nice smooth finish. Not polished, just smooth. Also left the lettering looking like it is one piece with the knob. Very slick.

Also, sanded the flat parts of the 2 halves with 220 grit to ensure a flush fit.

comments.text: How did you manage to remix this? I'm trying to remix it as well, replacing "WRX" with "STI" but I can't seem to find a viable method for doing so while keeping dimensions.
comments.author: surfmaster96

comments.text: Well, I had it easy, since the logo wasn't changing.  I'm not even very goo dat CAD yet- I am still using TinkerCAD most of the time, only dabbling in Fusion360.  I essentially chopped off the bottom & redesign that of the reverse lockout shifter, which needs a larger opening for the lockout mechanism that you lift up on.
comments.author: surfmaster96

comments.text:
Lol I wish I had seen this sooner, my bad! I ended up totally reconstructing the design based on measurements and using Fusion360. I traced the STI Logo in Illustrator then used an SVG of it to extrude into my finished model. I actually even moved the nut up in the model a bit so that it would have more strength between both parts and I made the lockout plate thicker for strength. I hope you're okay with me remixing it a bit. If you want you can check it out here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2467630
I will upload the Fusion360 files soon so that you can mess with it too.
comments.author: Dingoboy71

comments.text: Awesome!!!
comments.author: surfmaster96

comments.text: Haha glad you like it! There's two versions, one small, one big. If you want to add your own logos and stuff the Fusion360 file should be relatively easy to doctor. Thank you so much for allowing me to remix it!
comments.author: Dingoboy71

comments.text: Hey, mine was a remix to begin with, so I say- pay it forward, let everyone remix everything!!!  :-)   (But like you, I prefer to ask first)  Nicely done, by the way.  You're going to make a lot of folks happy with those designs.
comments.author: surfmaster96

This is a custom designed Star Wars lightsaber.

The SG90/9G servo is very popular - and every time I see it in a project (including my own) the little white plastic connector that comes with the servo is used (because the connector has tiny teeth that are not printable).

For my next project I wanted to use this servo but wanted to connect my part directly to the servo - so I made this.

If you zoom in you will see this isn't a round hole, inside there are tiny 0.5mm teeth.

Connecting this to the servo requires some force but it works really well.

Obviously this isn't a standalone object, this is for you to use in your designs to connect a servo, I've included the STL I printed to test the connector and the SketchUp source file.

Also obviously, you need a well calibrated printer to print 0.5mm features, so test-print it before doing anything that depends on it.

Note: it works if printed with the connector on the top or bottom of your print, havn't got it to work if the connector is on a side wall.

If you print it on the bottom and you squish the first layer you may need to carefully file the outer circle to get the servo to fit, be careful not to file the little teeth inside the connector.

Video showing how well it connects at https://youtu.be/A9TxGgDMwbg (there's a screw hole in the connector but it's not used in the video)

The test print was sliced with Cura and printed in PLA on my Robo3D R1+

A set of Algebra tiles for learning algebra. At my school we used these to learn about variables, the property of equality, and factoring quadratics. These are great because they not only teach you how to solve, but why it works. Here is a replacement set of tiles and I have added P to the positive sides of the tiles and boards and N to the negative side; I always found the colors confusing. This set includes a 1 tile, an x tile, a y tile, an x^2 and a y^2 in addition to a board and a plate of 16 one tiles

Simplicity and precision

I wanted a handspinner/fidget toy that was simpel yet elegant. Instead of playing with the rings i'm wearing, i needed something that was meant to keep my fingers busy and didnt make some noise.

After a few tries i ended up with 3 toys i liked, one with 4 bearings for maximum speed, one with 1 big bearing and 2 small bearings (Half speed) and one with 3 small bearings (halfspeed, but small (my EDC).

The small bearings have a diameter of 19mm and 6mm tall
The big bearings have a diameter of 22mm and 7mm tall (Skateboard bearing)

***** It's a tight fit, intentionell, so you might have to sand it down a bit. it's because i didn't want to clue it together. Precision is key!

Questions? Leave a comment and i'll respond as fast as possible!

I made one more, some people have asked for it. The last and final one consist of 3 big bearings (22mm) in a row. You can find that one here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1941506

title: Flashforge Creator Pro Filament Tube Bracket

description.text:
The late 2016 version of the Flashforge Creator Pro has modified the filament tube bracket into a really awkward to use V grip thing. This bracket clips into these V grips and greatly improves the filament handling. Simply press the bracket into the V grips (it takes a bit of force). The guide tube holes have a stopper at the bottom so the tube doesn't go all the way through.

A big advantage is that this bracket also moves the guide tubes out to the middle of the spools so you get smoother filament feeding. You will have to cut about 1" off the length of the filament guide tubes that are supplied with the printer.

description.text:
This is a small print-in-place (PIP) latch I designed to hold my extra Lulzbot toolheads inside my enclosure for my Taz5. I'm sure it can be used in a variety of other ways. I've included the .step files if you want to modify.

I just printed several extra X Carriage Guides from Lulzbot's Dev site here and mounted them on the wall. http://devel.lulzbot.com/TAZ/nutmeg/production_parts/printed_parts/x_carriage_guide/

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

80%

Notes:

I used Simplify 3D for slicing and manually placed supports under the extended arm only. The small gap that didn't have support bridged very well when I printed so ymmv. The layer height is somewhat arbitrary. I suspect it would print just fine anywhere between .2 and .35 layer height.

I designed in Fusion360. I had always wanted to try a print in place design and took the inspiration from the great Maker Faire Robot head rotation by LeFabShop that you can make out in the picture below. It's a rather simple hourglass shape with a .8mm clearance gap at the base and graduating down to a .5mm gap at the top to help a little with any first layer overage...

Made a simple split of JersyBeast's excellent Good Samaritan prop, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:582501, allowing the barrel assembly to be printed in three separate parts.

It's just for my printer to print it easier. Future versions may include lugs to keep things aligned.

IMPORTANT NOTE

Do a dry fit before gluing together! You'll get a better sense of the shapes that way. I'd also recommend bringing up a picture of the complete thing as reference.

Assembly

Fit the underbarrel to the main barrel. The top straight edge should go against the bottom of the main barrel. The triangular support should line up with the matching support in the back of the barrel and lie flush against the lower block.

Fit the underbarrel lug and front. It should slide right on, with the cut angular part against the barrel. Align the hollow of the lug and the underbarrel tube.

Glue. I'd suggest either epoxy or superglue.
Way too long spent wrestling with Blender.

description.text:
Small 18mm thumbwheels from manually adjusting beds on assorted derivative i3 kit printers. Replaces smaller metal thumbscrew nuts and wing nuts but should not bump into anything.

An M3 screw has a 0.5mm thread pitch when means a full turned of a bed leveling nut moved the bed 0.5mm. Two turns would be a full millimeter. The thumbwheel I designed has 10 points on it so every point is 0.05mm height change. Two points would move that corner of the bed up or down 0.1 mm.

I created another thumbwheel design that is too big for some of my newer i3 kits.

This thumbwheel works well with Tronxy X3, Zonestar P802M, Anet A8, and a few other i3 kits.

If you find this useful, please encourage me with a tip.

UPDATE: added a new version with the numbers in reverse per maker's correct logic: small_thumbwheel_rev2.stl <-- use this one from now one.

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12mm - 0.16mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Has a built in support ring that you should be able to push out with a 2.5mm hex wrench. A M3 nut should press fit into it.

3 shells.

Use a 2.5mm hex wrench to pop out the support ring.

Press in an M3 nut.

I used my drug of choice, Onshape.

Started the design on my iPad, then refined in on my iMac.

title: Audio-Technica ATH-M40X Replacement Hinge Connector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
MADE AT THE SAN DIEGO INNOVATION LAB @ THE SAN DIEGO CENTRAL LIBRARY!!!

The screw socket for the connector on the Audio Technica ATH-M40X breaks easily with normal use. This makes the cans (the speaker section) likely to fall off of the metal mount and cause further damage. After both broke on my headphones, I designed and printed this piece to get my headphones up and running again. Works just as well as the original, and is a hell of a lot sturdier. You use one of the original screws to fasten it to the metal bar and a zip tie to connect the front to the back. Glue is not recommended as it could prevent rotation.

author: chemteacher628

title: Snappy RepRap - Snap Together Printable 3D Printer

description.text:
The world's most printable 3d printer! (At least at the time I write this.)
A cheap, snap-together, nearly screw-less 3D printer (reprap) design that minimizes use of non-printed parts. Current parts cost: under $300, including the cost of plastic used to print the parts!

The two photos of parts shown above? Those were printed by my own snappy.

You can get the OpenSCAD sources at:
https://github.com/revarbat/snappy-reprap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Designed to be printed in PLA. You can probably use ABS or other materials, but the snap joiners may need glue or acetone to hold the parts together better if the finish is too slippery.

Assembly Tools

You will need the following tools to assemble this printer.

Qty Description
1 Multimeter for checking wiring.
1 Soldering iron.
1 Small rubber mallet to help convince some parts to join.
1 Mineral oil for lubrication.
1 Fine grit sandpaper to clean up the rails.
1 Optional cyanoacrylate glue. (super-glue)
Electronic Parts

You'll need controller electronics to drive the Snappy. Here's what I recommend. Prices given are based on what I found on Amazon with a cursory search. All

Qty Description Total Cost Where Found
1 Power Supply, 120W. (300W w/ Heated Bed) ~$20 Amazon.com
1 Controller electronics. (RAMPS1.4+2560+Pololus) ~$45 Amazon.com
3 Mechanical microswitch end-stops and wiring. ~$ 5 Amazon.com
5 NEMA17 Stepper Motors, 40mm length, 1m cable ~$65 Amazon.com
1 J-Head Extruder hot end w/heater, thermistor. ~$32 Amazon.com
2 40mm 12v 2-pin cooling fan, 10mm thick. ~$ 4 Amazon.com
1m Wire, dual conductor, 22 gauge, stranded ~$ 1 Amazon.com
1 Heated Build Platform. (optional) ~$ 9 Amazon.com
Non-Printable Hardware

You'll need the following Hardware to build the cartesian frame:

Qty Description Total Cost Where Found
2.4Kg Plastic Filament. (@ $30/Kg) ~$72 MatterHackers.com
2 ACME threaded rod, 3/8"-8 x 12" ~$18 McMaster.com
1 Extruder Drive Gear ~$ 4 Amazon.com
1 686 bearing. ~$ 1 Amazon.com
1 Borosilicate glass build platform. (213x200mm) ~$22 Amazon.com
4 Mini binder clips. ~$ 3 Amazon.com
Printed Parts

All parts should be printable inside a 150mm x 135mm x 110mm build volume.
The sled end-cap part, which is longer than 150mm, can be printed diagonally.

You will need to print out the following parts:

Qty Name
2 Rail X-Y Motor Segments (download)
1 Drive Gears (download)
4 Motor Mount Plates (download)
10 Rail Segments (download)
4 X-Y Slider Sleds (download)
2 X-Y Joiners (download)
2 Sled Endcaps (download)
1 Platform Supports Set (download)
2 Rail Y Endcaps (download)
2 Y-Z Bottom Joiners (download)
4 Support Legs (download)
2 Rail Z Motor Segments (download)
2 Lifter Rod Couplers (download)
2 Lifter Lock Nuts (download)
2 Z Slider Sleds (download)
1 J-Head Extruder Platform (download)
1 Extruder Motor Clip (download)
1 Extruder Idler & Latch (download)
1 Extruder Fan Shroud (download)
1 Extruder Fan Clip (download)
1 Cooling Fan Shroud (download)
1 Rail Z Endcap (download)
1 Spool Holder (download)
2 Cable Chain Link Sets (download)
1 Cable-Chain Mounts Set (download)

And one of the following motherboard mounts, depending on which electronics you use:

Qty Name
1 RAMPS MotherBoard Mount (download)
1 RAMBo MotherBoard Mount (download)

So, overall, about 160+ hours of printing.

Parts Assembly

Instructions for assembling the parts into the finished cartesian frame can be found at:
https://github.com/revarbat/snappy-reprap/wiki/Assembly

Connecting the Electronics

Refer to the wiring info given with the controller board of your choice.

Firmware Settings

I recommend Marlin firmware.
Whatever firmware you choose, though, here's the important parameters you're going to have to configure:

  • Steps/mm for X and Y axes: 80
  • Steps/mm for Z axis: 1007.875 for ACME 3/8"-8 threaded rod.
  • Steps/mm for extruder: About 96 (Will need calibration)
  • X & Y axes homes towards the minimum (negative) direction.
  • Z axis homes towards up/max/positive direction.
  • The X/Y position when homed is 0, 0
  • The Z position when homed is around 160, and you will need to calibrate this for your printer and extruder.

For Marlin firmware, edit these values in configuration.h:

#define MOTHERBOARD BOARD_RAMPS_13_EFF
#define TEMP_SENSOR_0 1
#define TEMP_SENSOR_1 0
#define INVERT_X_DIR false
#define INVERT_Y_DIR false
#define INVERT_Z_DIR false
#define Z_HOME_DIR 1
#define X_MAX_POS 190
#define Y_MAX_POS 190
#define Z_MAX_POS 160
#define MANUAL_Z_HOME_POS 160
#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT   {80, 80, 1007.875, 96.0}

For Marlin firmware, edit these additional values in configuration_adv.h:

#define CONTROLLERFAN_PIN 10
#define CONTROLLERFAN_SECS 300
#define EXTRUDER_0_AUTO_FAN_PIN 10

This is basically the result of trying out a bunch of ideas I had about how to replace non-printed parts in various reprap designs with printed parts. Since I'm a programmer, I wrote it all up in OpenSCAD.

To gain the best size fittings, print at 80% of actual size. To fit all the pieces together follow the numbered instructions. The magnets can be glued into the back of the base to turn it into a fridge magnet.

Tevo Dual Y Axis Linear Rod, was going to use Linear Rail but decided on Rod as its cheaper & in keeping with the printer’s great prints at a great price mantra, like any toy you can spend & spend $$$, & I wanted to print as much as possible,
the "Y" belt has pretension-er, This was Inspired by Dado Hajdarevic Design.

All pieces were printed at 0.2mm Layer Height, 50% fill, No support, Although you can use 10% fill for the 5mm belt adjusting nut & drilling Template, Or whatever suits.
You will need 2 x ( 8mm x 500mm ) Linear Rod & 4 x 8mm Linear bearing Block ( you can get away with 3 x blocks but I used 4, 1 x M5 x 20mm & 1 x M5 Nut For Adjustable end.
16 x M4x12mm hex socket screws.
Note : you can use support if you wish, Printing with No support was part of the design.

Using the original acrylic carriage plate, The drilling template was located using a 3mm screw & drilling 8 x 4.5mm holes on one side only. ( much easier than Measuring )
The other side I mounted the bearing blocks in the centre using cable ties to allow for any tolerance between printers/printing, Movement etc, using the drilling template I marked the 4 holes & filed the plate as it’s close to the edge.

I have updated / added Carriage Ends & Drill Template to suit 10mm Linear Rod & 10mm Bearing Block.

Update 9/11/206
I now have all 4 x Bearing block mounted near the corner of the Acrylic plate as I originally wanted. When I initially did this it was tight when they were all bolted down, so I placed the Bearing blocks to the centre on one side & secured them using cable ties as with similar printers assuming that printing &/or printing tolerances were to blame.
One of my bearing blocks was faulty/damaged & have replaced it.
See last photo.

Update 27/12/2016.
Modification to 8mm rear carriage, Electrical connection for stepper motor can now face the rear of the printer, Added holes opposite stepper motor instead of cutout for extra strength, allow allen key to tighten stepper motor mounting screws & easier removal / assembly of stepper motor pulley.

Update 5/01/2018.
Added Carriage ends to Suit 12mm Rod, Also Included drilling template to suit Acrylic carriage, Non of these have been printed, Have tested fitting in CAD software only.
updated to allow steeper motor connection to face the rear & extra hole to allow easier mounting of stepper motor.

title: Abardeen F80 wrist strap cradle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In the off-chance that you also own one of these extremely rare Chinese watch phones, you may have discovered that the detachable wrist strap is made from a poor quality plastic that becomes brittle and cracks over time. Spare parts are impossible to get, the model is no longer being manufactured and I doubt whether it can still be bought.

The photos show the original cradle at the right, which I have repeatedly repaired with epoxy glue and tape, but it was nearing the point where it became impossible to fix. One of the main reasons why I bought a 3D printer was to be able to print my own spares for cases like this. I finally got around to model and print one of the very first things that I thought I would be using my printer for.

The model is a very close replica of the original F80 cradle, only without all the weak points. The useless hole is gone and the base is slightly thicker. It provides a good snap mount without being overly tight. I printed it in ABS, but PLA will probably do fine too. You can detach the push pins from your original cradle with an xacto knife, or if it is unusable anyway, just break it…

Update 2017/01/14: a while later, the rubber strap itself also started to disintegrate, so I printed a replacement for it as well!

Update 2017/02/02: because the first version was a bit sloppy and the phone would move around in it, I created a new version v2 which has a better design, with a tab that sits tight against the phone, and two tiny spherical notches to further keep the phone secure. I printed this one with a support included in the model, and painted the underside with the same ABS filament dissolved in ABS, for a smooth underside without tiny gaps that could accumulate bacteria.

Update 2017/05/11: I completely destroyed my v2 print in an attempt to anneal it, so I took the opportunity to further improve the model before printing a replacement. Next to some small details, I added a few protruding tabs that provide ‘click’ action when pushing the watch in the cradle, so it takes a bit of force to release it. This should avoid that it shifts in the cradle when bumping against something or being subjected to shocks.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

It is essential to print this vertically (like in the model file) to provide maximum strength for the groove in which to mount the phone. This is also pretty much the only possible orientation to print it anyway.
The contact surface with the bed is extremely small, therefore it is also essential to use both a brim of at least 2 mm, and of course support material. For the first version I just let Slic3r do its job with pillar supports and it did the job well, I only tweaked the contact Z distance to be only 0.1 mm (one layer) to ensure good adhesion.
The print may become a bit wobbly in the topmost layers, but if the supports and brim are well-configured, this should not cause problems.
The downside of printing the model in this orientation is that layer adhesion is crucial to prevent the cradle from cracking in the same way as the original. Print this slowly and hot for maximum strength.

I printed the second and third versions in pretty much the same way, only with the fan speed reduced to 50%, because there was a small crack in the first version print due to too much cooling. The cooling is essential however to obtain an accurate and smooth print.

A parametric OpenSCAD file to create a recorder thumb rest for your current instrument. I set it up for my Aulos tenor, which I believe is an A511B. Set the "diameter" for the outside size of the thumb rest, and the internal_diameter for the diameter of your recorder at the point you wish the thumb rest to stay. You may have to fiddle the "offset" to get an object which OpenSCAD says is "Simple: yes" but which has enough edge to properly grip the recorder.

I printed this in ABS on a Folgertech Prusa 2020 i3. It took around 25 minutes. It's much better than the standard cork-and-rubber-band contraption. I have also successfully printed thumb rests for a chalmuneau and a "Xaphoon" ( basically a chalmuneau with a saxophone mouth piece). It works well with either ABS or PLA.

title: TwoPlus - Modular addon for Multi-color extruding

description.text:
TwoPlus permite imprimir con 3 filamentos de diametro 1.75mm con un solo nozzle.

Hay mas addons de este tipo, es solo que no encontre uno que permitiese 3 filamentos a la vez y me he decidido a diseñarlo.

Es modular porque permite adaptarse a cualquier tipo de impresora: prusa, sparkcube, etc. Ire subiendo los distintos modulos conforme los vaya diseñando.
ACTUALIZACION (16/10/2016):
-Chinese JHead Adapter Module (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1830945)

Tambien he añadido una herramienta para cortar comodamente el filamento pero ojo, tiene su peligro y yo declino toda responsabilidad derivada de cortes, amputaciones, facturas medicas y demas posibles accidentes con la hoja de cutter o el cutter en si.

ColorMixer esta en fase ALPHA, por lo que no os recomiendo desperdiciar filamento hasta que lo termine de desarrollar.

Esta pensado para usar los conectores neumaticos tipicos de los hotends chinos, que tienen un diametro aproximado de 9.5mm en la cresta de la rosca gas.

Como ya he comentado esta en fase ALPHA, sentiros invitados a solicitar medidas especificas para los diametros que necesiteis modificar.

Uso de la herramienta para el corte del tubo PTFE

Recomiendo que se taladre (a mano mismo) todo paso del tubo de teflon a 4mm. Absolutamente todo esta diseñado sin curvas para no dañarlo al repasar con la broca.

La herramienta se ha de apoyar en una mesa asegurada (que no se mueva) o superficie con canto recto (90º). Suelo usar la cuchilla sin la empuñadura del cutter en mi trabajo y me considero bastante diestro. La uso asi porque permite mas tacto y precision. El tubo de teflon (PTFE) es blando, id despacio y repasad las distintas crestas para que todo asiente correctamente. Lo ideal es que el corte siga el plano de la herramienta en cada corte para luego evitar los posibles huecos (que tampoco creo que sea nada critico, la verdad).

author: serrano_studio

description.text: Design for 3D artist magazine competition. Create a printable pet monster. I've always been fascinated with monsters/ creatures since I was a young whippersnapper. I ended up going for the imp/ gargoyle sort of design. I chose this design for the challenge of adding just enough detail for the muscle tone and facial features to come through in the final print. After experimenting with all sorts of poses and structures I decided to use a tucked position. This enabled me to model the full being in a fairly natural pose without having to split him up into bits. I wanted a clean, solid model with no nasty joints/ gaps etc. I was worried about overhanging sections of the model  and the possibility some parts sagging during printing (the hands in particular) but it turned out alright in the final print. Pleased with it :)

If you do take a shine to the little guy and decide to print one, I would love to hear your comments and see the final outcome.. so please feel free to comment and upload a picture of the print. :) 
GOYLE.STL is the higher res of the two stl files. GOYLE LOW.STL is smaller file. There is an OBJ file available. Feel free to mess about with it. :)
My 3D printing knowledge is pretty much NIL. Sorry guys! Any hints or helping comments would be appreciated. If there are problems with the model, let me know and I'll change and upload. 
If you want to make any changes to the file in order to get a better print, please feel free. 
Many Thanks! :)

description.text:
Geeetech Prusa i3 auto leveling induction sensor bracket:

I redesigned the leveling sensor bracket found on thingiverse. The originals were a little unstable and did not fit snugly.

This bracket is screwed down using the two existing screw and nut mount points. The addition top screw provides the needed stability. Also the part is designed to fit perfectly against this printers' extruder mount.

For the rest I followed:

description.text: This replaces the factory supplied 'turbo' fan of 40-50mm with a 80mm case fan of your choosing, I used a CoolerMaster, with rifle bearings to make it nice and quiet, and went with a slow speed since I am already almost quadrupling the amount of airflow. Mounts in the factory spot, with factory screws.

Designed this (very clumsily) in OnShape as a trial for what might be possible. Not a bad 3D software especially since I can pull stuff up on my phone and work on it. This is the link to the public version to modify at your hearts content.

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5801356b596faf10715dd3bf/w/fc6ba0a64c9435138ce84c62/e/42588b381273a99359110527

comments.text: Like everybody else i printed myself one of those half circle fan nossles which cooled my nossle and made the temp inconsistant. This adapter however did not only make it possible for me to print while the others were sleeping, but also corrected the set temp vs true temp issue.
comments.author: Nesolate

comments.text:
I just printed this adapter.
printed without any problems, nice design.
comments.author: kingofblocks

comments.text: The fan must have a really high static pressure to be able to work in this model. Most 50mm centrifugal fans produce roughly a maximum of 20mmH20 at a 12V supply voltage. In order to get the same amount of performance from a simple axial fan, you would need a similar static pressure, necessitating a Sunon/Vantec Tornado, or one of the Noctua brand Static Pressure fans. I am using a Tornado and have plenty of airflow through my system, though the fan is rather big and bulky and not at all quiet. (84cfm at 5700rpm) Sorry it didn't work for you, it was done because it was faster for me to print an adapter than order and wait for a new fan to come in.
comments.author: kingofblocks

comments.text:
I just printed one.
Design: 100%
comments.author: BerHerJohLin

comments.text:
Damn, I printed the adapter and ordered a 80mm fan today :'(. Probably a dumb question, but are you sure you put the fan in the right direction ? I'm surprised that there is no flow at all. Anybody know how much power the fan pin delivers ?
The turbine engine noise from the radial fan is getting me crazy (I measured 60 dB close to the fan...!)), I need a solution to get rid of that piece of s**t.
comments.author: BerHerJohLin

comments.text:
Maybe my Fan are to weak. (2.500rpm an 2.000rpm). they designed to make a "low noise" air stream.
I still hoping that it will work with the right fan.
comments.author: dEXtEr1ty

comments.text: 60m³/h is a huge air stream, what model did you buy ? 5000RPM is going to be noisy I guess. I don't think your 80mm is running at it's full speed. I'll keep you informed what result I get.
comments.author: BerHerJohLin

comments.text: 60m³ is for a 80mm Fan 2.000rpm not much i think.
comments.author: dEXtEr1ty

comments.text:
So, I set everything and it's working well. The air flow isn't that strong but obviously sufficient since I managed to print stuff without any difference than before (I replaced the radial fan only for a noise matter...)
I had to connect the 80mm fan to the "fan2" pin instead of the "fan1", for some reason it was stopping after a few minutes when juiced with the n°1, but now it's rotating at it's full speed (silently) permanently. I used that model (47.5 m3/h) > https://www.digitec.ch/en/s1/product/enermax-tb-silence-80mm-pc-fans-254067
comments.author: BerHerJohLin

comments.text:
Your Fan Model have a good Static Pressure (mm-H2O) -> 1,479
I don't know the value for my two models, but i think they have a bad one.
comments.author: dEXtEr1ty

comments.text: I start searching for Models with "High Static Pressure" ... i found a PSAD18025BH which absolutely screams along at 5100 RPM pushing about 70 CFM at 10.56 mmH20.
comments.author: BerHerJohLin

comments.text: I'm using a Vantec/Sunon Tornado that pushes about 84CFM at 5700rpm. It actually produces a maximum Static Pressure of close to 20mmH20. (I used to use two of these in a very cranky overheating PC that they were able to calm down.) I have really thought about switching to the Noctua fans since they have such a good reputation. Let me know what you find out when you try one.
comments.author: BerHerJohLin

comments.text: Works great!  Thanks for sharing, its a nice piece of engineering.
comments.author: caj411

comments.text: Hi there, nice design. Could you give me a short hint on how to wire the Collermaster fan properly? i have the same laying arround and decided to print your model, but I'am unsure about he wiring. Thx

remixed_from.author: Neo_Usagi
remixed_from.title: Updated E3Dv6 Shroud and 40 mm Duct w/ Magnetic Coupler

title: E3Dv6 Shroud and 40 mm Duct w/ Magnetic Coupler for 6x3mm Magnets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've modded the original with right hand filament cooler so the magnets I've lying around from my R/C hobby will fit.
The magnets are 6mm round shims and 2.9mm thick

Here is a link to the magnets I've used and that fit really perfect:
http://www.banggood.com/100pcs-N50-Super-Strong-Disc-Magnets-6mm-x-3mm-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-Magnets-p-997163.html

However, I didn't reduce the diameter of the original magnet mounting holes, so 1/4" magnets will also fit well

By request I've added a version with a 7mm lowered mount called "30mm_wnn_exotic.stl"
and one with an 8mm lowered mount that I think should work with an E3Dv6 with "VOLCANO" heater.
I have a "VOLCANO" lying around but not installed, so let me know if it works well for you.

Added a part called: "for clearance adjustment", if you have trouble with the clearance of the joint just ungroup the parts, stretch the insert to the size you need , slip it in place and cut it out with the .stl editor of your choice.
The most ease to do that is the free 3D Builder from MS what comes with should come with your if you use win10.

Printer:

Anet A8 B with E3D v6 bowden and RAMPS 1.4

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm with 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

25

Notes:

I've printed the combo with white ABS with Brim and it came out very well, lying in the fan side the 40mm doesn't need any support and the 30mm only under the magnet mount.

The 30mm fits really well and tight on the E3D v6 and caused by the little nose, the magnet mount need only one pair of magnets in the lower position.

The weight of my ABS combo is 15 gr. without magnets and fans.
The complete thing with magnets, both fans and a small 3 LED bracket weights 44gr.

comments.text:
I've added a part called: "for clearance adjustment" that you can use to simply modify the cutout of the joint inside the 40mm duct.
The part is in original size and comes in two pieces, the round and the square part.
Btw. don't think that difficult, for remixes or small adjustments, sometimes the low level software like 3D Builder will give you a much faster result that any high level software.
My thing is a remix without having any original files, only the .stl's and the little helper for you was made within two minutes or so. ;)

comments.text:
Sorry, at tthe moment I don't really understand your problem.
If you have an E3Dv6 and the original 30mm clip on fan fits, this one will fit too, cause it's also a clip on and the 40mm filament fan is mounted on the clip on housing of the 30mm fan.
You only need a little space to one more side for the 40mm, other than that your mount doesn't matter cause it's an E3Dv6 thing and the E3Dv6 will give you the right measurements.

description.text: This fan duct customizer creates a fan duct meant to mount on a hotend that has cooling fins, using the fins to hold the duct in place. It bears some improvement, but works well in testing. The fins on all-metal hotends with a small heat break tend to stay very cool at typical printing temperatures, so there's no issue printing this duct in PLA, but hardier materials like ABS may be better for some applications.

description.text: A bobble using the head of a model pig - see - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23029 - Lucky Pig. It is printed with PLA, a hard, rigid plastic, that makes a sensitive spring. The spring is a 3 dimensional version of Fermat's spiral, see - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1771653. OpenSCAD code is included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Notes:

The spring works well but cannot be constructed without support. To avoid excess support use a high support angle, say 82 or 83 degrees. Needle nose pliers can be used to remove most of the support; follow with tweezers for clean up.

Lucky_pig_head.scad takes lucky_pig_small.stl as input, extracts the head, and outputs lucky_pig_head.stl. Lucky_pig_bobble.scad takes lucky_pig_head.stl as input and outputs the bobble. Substitute an stl file of your choice for lucky_pig_small.stl to create your own head and pass it to lucky_pig_bobble.scad. Instructions are included in the openSCAD code.

The Mantis Walker is a two servo walking robot. I've included the build instructions as a PDF.

It uses an ultrasonic sensor to detect and avoid obstacles in it's path as shown in this video:
https://youtu.be/DYIM6IqTc4Q

Print out the body, the battery holder and the legs and follow the instructions to build.

I have included the Arduino sketch and the wiring diagram for the electronics is in the PDF.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

25

Parts Needed

All the electronics I got from ebay for about AUD$13.

The total list of parts I used:

Printed Mantis Body, Battery Holder and Legs
8 x 4G 6mm machine screws
2 x Tower 9G micro servos (which come with servo horns and screws)
1 x Ultrasonic Range Finder
Jumper Cables - male to male
1 x 9v Battery
1 x 9v Battery clip
1 x piece of Perfboard
1 x Arduino Nano
Female header pins or Nano socket
Male Header pins (need 3 + 3 + 4)
1 x PCB switch (optional)
1 x PCB battery header male and female
Hook up (pref. single core) wire

title: Aviation, XT60, and Power Panel thing

description.text:
Another panel thing i made for my cnc pc. This one is substantially larger, follows no hole pattern for the mounting, or really anything.

Uses 6 of some 16mm round aviation style connector things. Not really sure what they are called. Just got some cheap ones from chinabay.

Also includes holes for 2 XT60 connectors which get clamped in with 2 #4-40 screws each.
And then theres space for a toggle switch, and then finally a plug for a power cord.

Turns out not all C14 plugs (the computer plugs) are the same, so a little filing/shaving may be required for that hole.

title: DailyEarring#109: Woolwinder (with gears, video inside)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Minimalist wool winder (not as cool as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13816 ! - go there if you are looking for a usable version ;-)) Short working demo:
http://youtu.be/b-U9HqYEUDY While I used string in thingiverse.com/thing:17822 I now managed to use a gear! Unfortunaly, at this scale, it does not run very smoothly. Sometimes it needs to be pushed further or wiggled around.
But the heck with it, it's an earring. Who would need such tiny skeins anyway? :-) If anyone wants to give me a UV-resin or SLS printer though, I'd happily accept. For a angled gear it is too small of a print. I hate gears at this scale :-)
I would appreciate any suggestions though! If you don't know how these work: The thing turns string into a skein (through magic!).
The skein holder spins arround the base and turns itself. This way a tidy criss-cross pattern will be created instead of a random lump of string.
This is the reason why the top gear goes arround the axis. The axis remains still and acts as friction wheel or gear to turn the skein at a lower rate.
(I hope I got it explained right, it's late here...)
More Info on the semi-daily-earrings: thingiverse.com/thing:7120

Print. Assemble with instant glue. Check out the Sketchup/Images for assembly. I tried to make it glue-less but it's either too tight or too loose to withstand the force when the crank is turned. Hints: First stick the hollow gear into the big hole, then the crank-gear-part (use tweezers, insert it 45Â°, it's a little fiddly to make the gears go into each other AND into the holes ;-) )
Use tweezers or something that stays in place to press the crank-gear in place. Glue the crank to the shaft.
Glue the top spinning part (clean with exacto) onto the hollow gear. Hold in place with tweezers or so.
When glue is dry, push rod into the assembly, glue to the bottom hole (with the UP, the hole actually goes through, but it's no big deal. I had to scrape the top part of the rod for a snug fit). There is a small gear but it's a bit too big and for this model the disc has sufficient friction.
At the end, assemble the wool holder. If I would print it 1.5x it might even work, though it would require adjusting (play/gaps/gear teeth...) At 1:1 I tried angling the gear teeth but it did not help much at that resolution.... I want a UV resin printer with high resolution :-( I included a small gear for the top, but it's too big, but as mentioned before - It's not really necessary. Yes, I know the real thing should have a higher gear ratio, but I wanted to keep it as small as possible.

comments.text: That is about the coolest thing I've seen, it's so tiny!

author: DaeHyuk

title: SIMPLE Filament Spool Holder for the MakerBot

description.text: This is a simple filament spool holder to be mounted on top of a MakerBot. 100% MakerBot printable. Requires no non-printable parts other than PVC glue or epoxy.

You will need some kind of ABS or PLA-friendly adhesive such as epoxy, PVC glue (and primer; either purple or clear), gorilla glue, JB Weld, etc. to complete this project. Download and print the following: Base
Stem
Bottom
Top Attach the base to your MakerBot using one of the existing square caps the front-top of your machine. Glue the "fat" end of the stem into the smaller hole in the "bottom" piece. Drop the "thin" end of the stem into the base once the glue has cured. Place your filament spool over the "bottom" section of the spool and insert the "top" into the spool and "bottom". Its pretty self-explanatory once you print everything. Note: You do not need to glue the stem into the base. I allow it to "float" inside the base for low friction. You can use glue but it is not required.

title: Igus 8mm bushing and SC8UU compatible housing

description.text:
The bushings are made from Igus filament (size 8X12X12), the housing can be PLA, ABS whatever. Igus supplies stl files for their standards press fit bushing but these are too thin. The one I designed are thick enough, a bit oversized so you can bring them to the correct sizes and finish and are to be press fitted too. You have to finish the exterior with abrasive or files but for the inside, better to use a reamer or eventually a good sharp drill bit once installed to get the proper diam and finish. Done properly will lead to virtually no play, yet a smooth travel.

For linear motion, the bushing with groves works best.

They are smaller, shorter, lighter than the chinese LM8UU series yet are better and can be used with cheap SS rods. These don't last long with ball bearings as they are too soft.

The housing is compatible with the SC8UU, just shorter, only two screws. Use self tapping screws, 3.2mm is OK, bigger may require drilling the holes. Regular M3 or M4 are OK too, not really needed to tap, just drill as required before tapping (diam minus pitch).

No messy lubrication required. Note that you need to properly align the bushings. Use the smooth rod to help. This is always true. The way LM8 are installed in most 3D printers is just the opposite of good engineering practice (split housing, tiewrap) but required because of poor design and alignment. The elasticity of the assembly will cope with it.

On the pictures, you can see them installed on my Geetech Prusa Al Y table (the housing is a previous non press fit design) and integrated in the X carriage of my own. For the X, I used two, one at each end.
To get a pretty good alignment, you can heat the housings once installed with a heat gun to relieve the stress. I did it for the Y table. Not required for the X carriage as I reamed the two bushings in one go with a long reamer once installed.
You can see the grooves left by the LM bearings ! Was time to phase them out.
They have been running for a few months now, a couple 1kg spool.

The Y table is more than 150g lighter than the original and my X carriage plus extruder, hot end etc is about 250 g, less than the weight of just the supplied MK8 Nema 17 motor !

Note that an added advantage of these bearings is they somewhat dampen vibration and are silent contrary to the LM bearings that rattle so much they can drive people crazy. (if they don't rattle it means they are stressed because of misalignment and will soon fail :) )

PS:
-Igus supplies drop in bearings (Drylin) similar to the LM, SC series used in 3D printer. They are fine but lead to bigger, heavier parts. Longer too wich is unnecessary here due to the light loads and they have therefore more friction. And what about the fun to do your own ?
-Standard bronze bushing (8X12X12) can be used instead of the printed Igus bearing.

comments.author: scardturtl

comments.text:
I'm shocked, here in Switzerland they asked me around 120€ for a spool so i tried with there sample material witch was only about 5 meters. But i agree, for this price there are many ideas where it can be used. I think i have to talk with the vendor or, probably order it somewhere else.
thanks for the info and go ahead.
comments.author: rfeierabend

comments.text: I also tried to use self printed bearings with Igus filament but i was not confident with the result. So i ordered some original finished bearings from igus. I found them, dearth cheap in ebay ( Item# RJ4JP-01-08, cost: 16 € for 12 pieces). So it's not worth to spend a lot of money for the filament to get a printout witch doesn't really fulfill the requirements.
comments.author: rfeierabend

comments.text:
A spool of Igus filament is around 30€ and let you design what you want. I wanted to experiment and was positively surprised by the results.
You can replace not just linear bearings. I posted here a ball bushing for ex. I designed my extruder where I use it in lieu of ball bearings. Looking for V groove,aluminium profile etc.... on a new printer too. I could even use it as a combination nut and bushing on TR8 lead screws for the Z of my Prusa, the screws is straight enough.
It is a fact that just out of the printer, they are not suitable and require tool and expertise to get good results.
Of course for production it would be better to buy the Igus bushings. But the selection is so plentiful, better experiment first with your own isn't ?

This is a mounting bracket to hold a piece of 5/16 inch (8mm) threaded rod at a right angle to a wall for holding a filament spool.  It uses a captive nut in the back to hold the rod in place.
I plan to coil small sections of filament cut from a bundle on this after the current spool runs out as the humidity control in my apartment isn't the best and I don't want to expose a full roll to it. I'm going to add a winding handle to make that easier but my printer is down for emergency repairs.

• Print this somewhat solid. I didn't use supports and the nut trap caved in marginally during printing.
  • Find a stud in your wall and mount (remember the captive nut)
  • Screw the rod in and tighten a nut on the outside
  • Print 608 bearing hubs for your spool. I used the ones from this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16767

The goal:
-Serviceable hot end on the front over the support
-Annealing on the build plate
-Zone controlled heated bed ~900W
-E3D volcano, dual and/or Diamond head

Waiting for deliveries:

  • 12x600mm Y and Z guides
  • brass/graphite bushings
  • 500W 24V PSU (wide input)
  • steel backed GT2 belts

To design:

  • Front brace to prevent torsion of motor mounts
  • Octoprint display and C2/Pi enclosure
  • Z axis support for hollow stepper and ball lead screw

To fix:

  • longer X axis shafts going trough the support for more stability

Tested and working
-Closed loop Nema23 XY axis
-Titanium shaft for X gantry
-Rumba
-Limit switches

This frame is limited by the Atmel processor speed ...

This is a reconstruction of the washer that keeps the crane stock pipe of an M4 airsoft rifle attached to the receiver. I broke the original trying to tighten up a rickety stock pipe. The original was made from a cheap, brittle metal alloy that cracked without warning. Standard 5 mm opening for the screw through the centre, with a small cutaway to allow the battery leads to pass through. Printed in PLA at 100 % infill. Tested on an M4A1 replica. A tight fit, but so far it does the job. I may put some more enforcement on it if it turns out to break too easily.

Longways, or sideways sliding bracket. I'm using it to hold one tool display to another, but the uses are pretty wide and far.
Seems to work better in ABS, than in PLA, and I've been going with a 30% infill, and using one on top and one on the bottom. If you were going to mount something heavier I would suggest 2 or more, and a higher infill.
You'll need both files to print the complete bracket.
I designed a square one first, but it didn't last long. The flange seems to be a lot stronger and useful.

title: Kossel Mini Reel Holder for Large Hubs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Slot mount Kossel Mini reel holder, suitable for larger reels.

Three of these are printed and mounted to the top of the printers frame. The reel rides on the lower bearings and inside of the upper bearings.

The additional washer allows the direct replacement of existing reel holders that include a guide without finding another bolt.

The following hardware is needed for these mounts:
6 x 625 bearings of any type
6 x M5x18mm bolts
6 x M5 nuts
6 x M5 washers
3 x M3x7mm bolts
3 x M3 T/V slot nuts
